Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Why Does Oxidation Improve Freezing? Using Laboratory Measurements and Molecular Simulations to Investigate Heterogeneous Ice Nucleation on Carbon Surfaces
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Environmental Chemical Sciences (ECS) program of the Division of Chemistry supports the collaborative research efforts of Sarah D. Brooks (Texas A&M University) and Valeria Molinero (University of Utah) to investigate the heterogeneous nucleation of ice on model organic surfaces and soot using an unprecedented combination of laboratory measurements and molecular simulations. The primary objective of this project is to evaluate which specific chemical and physical properties of carbonaceous surfaces modulate their ability to act as ice nuclei for water freezing. The second objective is to elucidate the heterogeneous mechanisms of formation of ice on these surfaces. Previous laboratory results suggest that oxidation processes representative of atmospheric aging improve the ice nucleating ability of aerosols, facilitating contact freezing at warmer temperatures. Oxidation, however, alters carbon surfaces not only by incorporation of hydrophilic groups but also through a modification of the nanostructure of the surface. Laboratory experiments will be conducted to determine the prerequisite temperature and relative humidity required for immersion and deposition freezing on hydrocarbon and oxidized hydrocarbon particles. Simulations will be used to determine the effect of nanostructure, chemical modifications, and hydrophilicity of the surface on the freezing temperatures, the heterogeneous mechanism of formation of ice, and the size and structure of the critical ice embryo.

Abundant in the atmosphere due to anthropogenic and biogenic sources, carbonaceous particles display a wide range of effectiveness in promoting the nucleation of ice in clouds. This variability causes major uncertainties in predictions of the effect of aerosols on climate. The project will lead to an improved understanding of the phase of water in the atmosphere and assist in the parameterization of global climate models. A workshop to train high school teachers in the use of freely available molecular visualization software to develop classroom activities that complement and enhance the high-school curriculum will be developed at the University of Utah. The molecular visualization tools and the simulations that display the formation of ice will be incorporated into undergraduate courses taught by the PIs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the atmosphere, there are numerous pathways leading to the formation of ice crystals. Aerosol-cloud interactions and specifically ice nucleation are major uncertainties in global climate models to date. Homogeneous freezing only occurs at temperatures below ~ -36 °C. Above this temperature, water droplets freeze when catalyzed by an ice-nucleating particle (INP) either in contact with or immersed within the droplet. This collaborative project combined laboratory measurements at Texas A&M University with modeling studies conducted at the University of Utah. The laboratory measurements were conducted to determine the freezing temperatures of water droplets in contact with various types of aerosol particles found in the atmosphere, and the modeling was used to probe details of the underlying freezing process and the chemical and physical characteristics which allow certain particles to catalyst freezing more effectively than others.  

This project determined the freezing temperatures of water droplets in contact with a wide range of carbonaceous aerosol compositions, including soot, polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon, and long chain alkanes and alkenes. Our measurements expand the range of organic aerosols which can act as INP and includes a subset of aerosols present in the liquid phase. The overarching conclusion of this study is that organic compounds found in the atmosphere are all approximately equally effective as contact INP, despite differences in molecular structure, chain length, degree of oxidation, and even phase. Taken together, liquid, glassy, and solid organic aerosols comprise a large fraction of atmospheric INP which is currently underrepresented in most climate models.

Our laboratory experiments indicate that oxidation increases the mean freezing temperature by 2-3 K for all solid ice nucleating particles (INP). We note that oxidation of solid carbonaceous aerosols increases their hydrophilicity and also the nanostructure of the particles. Using molecular modeling we demonstrate that the increase in freezing temperature upon oxidation is not due to increase in the hydrophilicity of the surface; the nanostructure and topology of the ice nucleating surface is at least as critical as the chemistry of the surface in determining its ice nucleation ability. We expect that our results will rekindle a discussion on what are the important variables in ice nucleation and increase awareness of the need to characterize ice nucleating surfaces beyond their composition.

Our observations of liquid aerosols catalyzing the freezing of water droplets is significant because it broadly expands the populations of organic aerosols in the atmosphere that nucleate ice.  Ours is the only study in which the temperature-dependent viscosity was measured on the same samples for which ice nucleation temperatures were determined. We find that even moderately viscous organic aerosols are capable of acting as ice nuclei, and this includes a large population of aerosols not previously considered in modeling of ice nucleation. 

Accurate climate modeling hinges on good predictions of the rate of ice nucleation. Such rate estimates are based on extrapolations using classical nucleation theory, which assumes that the structure of nanometer-sized ice crystallites (a few hundreds water molecules) corresponds to that of bulk hexagonal ice, the thermodynamically stable form of ice. Using simulations and theory we show that the stable polymorph of nanometer-sized ice crystallites is not hexagonal ice but stacking disordered ice (formed by sequences of cubic and hexagonal ice layers). This results in over three orders of magnitude higher nucleation rates with respect to classical nucleation theory predictions. The results of our work provide correction to classical nucleation theory and should have a strong impact on climate models.

This collaborative project has provided an opportunity to strengthen interactions between scientists working on laboratory measurements and molecular dynamics modeling. Graduate student Kristen Collier from Texas A&M was responsible for all laboratory experiments. Postdoctoral fellow, Lara Lupi, and graduate students Andrew Nguyen and Pavithra Naullage were responsible for the molecular modeling and theory. As part of the postdoctoral mentoring program, Dr. Lupi visited the laboratories of Texas A&M, learnt the details of the ice microscope and experimental procedure and worked with Collier. In addition, Dr. Lupi gave the Atmospheric Science Departmental Seminar. The results of this collaborative project were disseminated in 46 presentations (15 by the students and postdoc) in seminars, workshops, and conferences and 10 peer-reviewed journal articles. Research in this project was part of the dissertation of two graduate students (Kristen Collier 2016 and Andrew Nguyen 2015).

This project has also provided positive research opportunities for two REU students, Wilson and Suarez, who presented their work at national meetings.  This project reached high school students through a) a learning module on climate research, including the modeling and laboratory measurements of ice nucleation, presented to high school students through the annual TAMU Youth adventure Program (YAP) and b) the workshop “The Growth of Crystals in 3D” presented to multiple cohorts of students yearly through Science Day at the University of Utah.
